name: iptables
desc: iptables is a command-line tool used to manage network traffic control rules and security policies on Linux systems.

-A.name: Insert a rule into the chain

-D.name: Delete a rule from the chain

-I.name: Insert a rule into the chain at a specified position

-R.name: Replace a rule in the chain

-L.name: List the rules in the chain

-F.name: Flush all the rules from the chain

-Z.name: Zero the packet and byte counters for all the rules in the chain

-P.name: Set the policy for the chain

-C.name: Check whether a rule exists in the chain

-S.name: Print the rules of the chain in a format that can be used as input to iptables-restore

content:
Example

  • Reject all traffic: iptables -P INPUT DROP
  • Allow all traffic: iptables -P INPUT ACCEPT
  • Allow loopback traffic: iptables -A INPUT -i lo -j ACCEPT
  • Allow HTTP traffic: iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j ACCEPT
  • Allow SSH traffic: iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT
  • Allow DNS traffic: iptables -A INPUT -p udp --dport 53 -j ACCEPT
  • Allow ICMP traffic: iptables -A INPUT -p icmp -j ACCEPT
  • Show current rules: iptables -L
  • Flush all rules: iptables -F
  • Zero all counters: iptables -Z
